title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,

snippet: The road is steep and irregular ; and ere long, on turning round, you will discern, beyond the lake, stretching westward ftom the mouth of the river Leven, a long stripe of sea.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Broad between Bell- Grange and MiUer-Ground — with no isle to break the breadth of liquid lustre — but with an isle anchored to windward, on whose tall trees are seen sitting- some cormorants — broadest of all its bending length from the Giants of Brathay to the humble holms of Landing, where in mild metamorphosis it narrows itself into a river, the lucid Leven — Hes the bosom of Windermere.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: On the shore here, but so covered with ivy as to be scarcely perceptible, stands the ruinous castle of Leven, an ancient possession of a family of the surname of ]\Iorton, from which it was transferred in the year 1547 to William Lord Semple.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: A mile further on is the small village of Methill, and, at the distance of another mile, the village of Leven, situated  at the mouth of the river of the same name, which issues from Loch Leven.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Amongst other articles agreed upon betwixt the Englishand Scottish commissioners for the final pacification of theBorders, 9th April, 1605, after recommending that all deadlyfeuds should be put to agreement, or those who refused toacquiesce should be detain prisoners, that heavy mulcts andpenalties should be inflicted on such Scottishmen and Englishas broke the peace by any act of violence, and that robbersfrom either country should be punished with death, there isa clause ofthe following tenor:—" Also.it is agreed that proclamation shall be made, that all inhabiting within Tindaleand Riddesdale in Northumberland, Bewcastledale, Wilgavey, the north part of Gilsland, Esk and Leven in Cumberland,East and West Tevidale, Liddesdale, Eskdale, Ewsdale, andAnnerdale, in Scotland, (saving noblemen and gentlemen unsuspected of felony or theft, and not being of broken clans.)and their household servants dwelling within those severalplaces before recited, shall put away all armour and weapons,as well offensive as defensive, as jacks, spearB, lances, swords,daggers, steelcaps, hagbuts, pistols, plate sleeves, and suchlike ; and shall not keep any horse, gelding, or mare, above

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Above that house is a romantic glen,or cleft of a mountain, covered with hanging woods, having atbottom a stream of fine water that forms a number of cascades in its descent to join the Leven, so that the scene isquite enchanting.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: It mighthave been placed in a higher situation, which would haveafforded a more extensive prospect, and a drier atmosphere ;but this imperfection is not chargeable on the present proprietor, who purchased it ready built, rather than be at thetrouble of repairing his own family-house of Bonhill, whichstands two miles from hence on the Leven, so surroundedwith plantations, that it used to be known by the name oftheMavis (or thrush) Nest.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance

snippet: "Yes, sirs, I am boune for Edinburgh, and havebeen thrice beset by horsemen, and thrice have swam ariver, the Leven, the Ore, and the Lochtie!"

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: Oaths and cries of rage resounded among the woodsbehind, and many a trooper urged his horse towards theblink, but theh hearts failed them, and not one daredto cross the deep and rapid Leven, by which theirintended victim had been saved, and theh leader sweptaway before their eyes.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance

snippet: On, on yet! and he soon foundhimself among the woods of the Leven; dark and thick,old md stately, the beeches were in the sud fohage ofJuly, and the dense old Scottish firs intertwined theirwiry tranches with them : and now the river, broad, deep,and hoarse, in the fuU fury of its summer flood, swoUenby a right of rain, lay rolling in foam before him; andupon is opposite bank rose, from a wooded eminence,the strong and lofty donjon tower of that timehonourel, but now extinct race, the brave old Lundiesof Balgoiie.
